awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Infusing Machine Learning in Cognitive Psychology and Cognitive Bias Analysis: Enhancement of the Computer Science and Psychology Curricula
awd_abstract_narration:
The Targeted Infusion Project (TIP) at Fisk University seeks to implement a novel infusion of the computer science and psychology curriculum. This project will enhance psychology students? abilities to understand artificial learning and cognition. This project will also develop a course in machine learning focused on social sciences. Novel aspects of this proposal include: providing an introduction to machine learning (ML) and applications to social science for balanced algorithm development; offering an experience of understanding learning and bias related to artificial intelligence (AI) protocols; creating computer science and social science curriculum modules relating to bias and learning in ML and AI ; and offering this experience at a HBCU, so that underrepresented students are funneled into STEM graduate schools and careers.

This proposal will incorporate quantitative methods and include research into lecture and laboratory components of social science and computer science courses. The goal of this project is to innovate the curriculum in order to better prepare students in the social sciences and computer sciences  for an increasingly multidisciplinary worldview: 1) develop an introductory machine learning course for social sciences which balances between core machine learning concepts as well as application and implication to the social sciences, 2) develop a  psychology course that focuses on deep learning paradigms in learning and cognition, 3) develop modules for other computer science and psychology courses which reinforce the connections between computer science and psychology. Together the objectives will provide a strong foundation in core scientific skills, particularly quantitative skills in computation, cognitive development, algorithm assessment, and problem solving. This interdisciplinary approach will synergize with several ongoing initiatives at Fisk University and have a transformative effect on student training, learning and careers in STEM disciplines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Under the auspices of this grant, Fisk successfully developed a cross-functional curriculum between social science and computer science that instructs students on social and psychological bias. The objectives of the project were: 1) develop a modified social science curriculum pathway that incorporates machine learning, 2) develop a modified computer science curriculum pathway that incorporates social bias protocols within the machine learning courses, and 3) disseminate information through journals and conference attendance.

Accomplishments

Courses related to Modeling and Machine Learning were modified to include Racial Bias included: CSCI 280 - Mathematical Modeling, CSCI 390ML - Machine Learning for Social Sciences, CSCI 390DS - Data Science for Social Justice, CSCI 390 - Machine Learning, and PSY 262 - Learning & Cognition, in which students participated in an implicit bias lab. Fisk University also launched a masters degree program in Data Science. Students learned Python programming, including creating GUI workflows for machine learning models. Students were also trained in understanding image and face recognition models and their limitations.  Students in the Machine Learning for Social Sciences (MLSS) course developed and tested coding modules, which enabled them to address a broad array of computational problems, as well as troubleshoot the Python code for the machine learning model. The students addressed problems from analysis to visualization. They learned regression algorithms (e.g. linear, logistic, SVM) and the application of neural networks and decision trees. They also learned how these tools could be applied to different socially relevant problems (e.g. policing, voting, etc.). Students working on the Cognition Bias in Artificial Intelligence course learned the pervasive nature of bias, studying implicit bias in humans and in machine learning applications, and relations between learning in humans and artificial intelligence. Students learned the real-world effects of bias, as well as the importance of stakeholder (programmers, designers, implementers, etc.) awareness of their own potential biases. Students also learned the strengths and limitations of the Implicit Association Test (IAT). Students also engaged in a summer internship with training in coding and cognitive bias. Students from different majors (Psychology, Sociology, Criminal Justice, Data Science, Computer Science, Biology, Biochemistry) took these courses and benefited from the curriculum innovations. Students also participated in the Annual Fisk Research Symposium.

Impact

Students working on the Cognition Bias in Artificial Intelligence course learned the pervasive nature of bias, studying implicit bias in humans and in machine learning applications, and relations between learning in humans and artificial intelligence. Students learned the real-world effects of bias, as well as the importance of stakeholder (programmers, designers, implementers, etc.) awareness of their own potential biases. Students also learned the strengths and limitations of the Implicit Association Test (IAT). Students completed a survey that spoke to the impact the initiative had on them. Most students reported that they were at least competent at understanding the dangers of bias in AI (73.9%), understanding how/why bias exists in computer systems/software (65.2%), conducting exploratory data analysis to determine appropriate demographic representation (65.2%), and applying ML tools to real-world applications/use (60.9%). Approximately 48% of students reported that they were at least competent at developing strategies for minimizing bias and that they could apply ML tools to real-world applications.

Modified by: Sheila Peters
